{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3687783,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-23T17:09:41.224Z","cooked":"

I know that the DS indicates disabled when the robot is powered on. However looking at the code for TimedRobot and IterativeRobotBase it seems to me that there is a None mode that occurs and bypassing any mode init method. Is this the case or is this simply the situation on first loop run where the robot immediately enters disabled mode

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-07-23T17:09:41.224Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":141,"readers_count":140,"score":38.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504559,"topic_slug":"startup-mode-question","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/startup-mode-question/504559/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3687898,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-23T17:57:04.774Z","cooked":"

Of note:

robotPeriodic() is called regardless of mode (including for None)

Source code

The promise I’m aware of is that as each of teleop/auto/test/disabled mode starts, you get one call to the init function, then periodic calls to the periodic function.

Beyond that I’m not sure there’s an API promise, specific to “None” or really anything beyond the above four options. I’m also kinda curious how one gets into this boat today (but I wouldn’t build any code around that assumption I think).

FWIW the vast majority of our robot code gets called from robotPeriodic() intentionally - we know regardless of mode or driver station hookup or anything, our periodic controls code will keep updating.

It is interesting though, because (today) if the robot transitioned from “teleop” to “none” without going through any disabled, we’d hold the last operator inputs and continue to attempt to command motors through calls to robotPeriodic.

I do assume that the Universal Heartbeat and other safety protocols kick in for “Not Auto or Teleop or Test”, rather than “Is Disabled” - throwing None in there makes those statements different.

It is not possible for it to exit that if/else chain with mode set to None. If the robot is not disabled, one of those three auto/teleop/test functions will return true (the boolean logic in the DSControlWord class for those 3 functions ensures that).

I think the long and short of it seems to be in this case Java

Standard Java init sequence (static fields, instance field, constructor)

Then robotInit : Though it seems that even though it still exists we should just use the Robot() constructor.

simulationInit(): if in sim

disabledInit(). The repeated calls to disabledPeriodic, robotPeriodic, and simulationPeriodic (if in sim). until a mode switch
